LACROSSE GAME WITH TORONTO
Ad Club Arranges Big Contest—Hopkins
Rooters Must Be in Stands Before Half-past Three.

An All-Johns Hopkins lacrosse
team, having in its lineup some of
the best players turned out in
recent years, wit meet the Toronto
Athletics on Homewood field on
Thursday afternoon at 4.30 o'clock
as part of the schedule of the Associated Advertising Clubs' program of festivities during their
convention week in this city.
In selecting lacrosse as the particular sport that would be/interesting to the advertisers, a unique

compliment was paid Johns Hopkins. It was seen that a game between the 'Varsity and the Toronto
Athletics, considered by many the
best twelve on this continent, would
be close and interesting. The Canadians have been champions of the
Senior Interassociation Lacrosse
League of Canada for three years,
and their style of play is considered
standard by the Northern twelves.

THE MADISON

is put in the first class of colleges
of this country.
Dr. J. Morris Slemons, associate
professor of obstetrics at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital, has accepted the
offer to become director of the new
Women's Clinic and professor of
obstetrics and gynecology at the
University of California. He will
leave Baltimore on July 15, and
will take up his new duties on
August 15. Dr. Slemons took his
A.B. degree here in 1897, and his
M.D. in 1901.
Dr. von Noorden,son of the prominent Vienna physician, will become
one of the assistant resident physicans at the hospital, and is expected
to assume his new duties in October.

The Faculty Reception.

After the conferring of degrees
Tuesday afternoon, the graduates
can look forward to the evening,
when the faculty of the University
will tender them a reception in McCoy Hall. This is always the .most
enjoyable social event of the whole
school year. It beats the best of
the cotillons. The event is always
a sort of cosmopolitan affair. Dress
suits and white flannels are both
seen; gay young A.B.'s with their
pretty partners are mixed among
the papas and admiring mammas.
° eems to be an abunThere always s
dance of all sorts of delicacies, and
when the floor has been newly
greased after the final "exams," the
fine dance music is enough to set
anyone's toes to tipping the floor.
The guests are invited to enter McCoy Hall by the south door, and
they will be received at 9 P. M.
Admission. will be by ticket only.

BALTIMORE, MD., JUNE 9, 1913.
Rooting Next Thursday.

The plan to have a rooting section for the game with the Toronto
Athletics deserves our most earnest
support. At Homewood, on Thursday, will be gathered a crowd of
big business men from every State
in the union. It is up to us, we
who are not lacrosse players, to
show that Hopkins has got as
much college spirit as any college
in the country. We must so thoroughly • impress the name "Hopkins" on those advertising men that
they shall never forget us.
Of course everybody is going to
the game—that goes without saying. There is to be a roped off
section under the old pine tree.
As the game is called at fourthirty, we should have the stand
filled with Hopkins rooters by four
o'clock, for fear the crowd will disregard our ropes, and fill the section.
"Freddie" Lee will be on hand, in
his usual form. But is is up to
you, you who know the cheers, to
come up in :that section and YELL.
We are champions of the Southern Division. Here's a long 'rah
with a daisy on the end for the
International Championship!
1913's Achievements.

This year's graduating class is
most to be commended for its
praiseworthy exertions in making
the second annual Senior Week a
success. Last year the novelty of
their doings made it easier for
1912 to get the necessary support
of the rest of the college. This
year the task was more severe.
That Chairman Richardson and his
sub-chairman have given us a most
pleasurable week can best be
brought out by a short summary
of the different festivities.
The most frequently used phrase
in connection with the senior prom

was "Best-ever." Everyone on
the "Annapolis" wished the machinery had broken before we got
to Fort Howard, that we might
have remained on the water hours
longer. The field day and dinner
of Saturday will long remain a
bright spot in 1913's memories of
Johns Hopkins. The play this
afternoon was a giggle and a gasp
from curtain to curtain. In brief,
the seniors so far surpassed the
Senior Week of last year that the
three other classes are wondering
how they are to maintain such a
record.
And the seniors have done more;
they have revived an old tradition. After a lapse of four years
another "Hullabaloo" has come before the public. The class of 1913,
and particularly the Board of Editors, deserves high commendation
for the quality of their book. From
cover to cover it is cleverly gotten
up; the binding is very attractive,
and the interior ably fulfills the
promise of the outside.
Manager Richardson wants everybody to buy their "Hullabaloos" before next Saturday. The increase
crom $2.00 to $2.50 in the cost of
the book has been made necessary
to clear expenses.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure
in being able to announce that it is
officially reported that a majority of
the undergraduates passed their examinations. We sympathize with
the minority.

fOWNES
LOVES

The Senior Play.

We hold it to be a self-evident
truth thdt comparisons are odious.
Therefore, we shall not compare
this year's senior play with the one
given last year, although it certainly
was more ambitious; it was built
around a real plot, which, though
simple, held the interest of every
hearer from beginning to end; and
the staging was far better. The
acting was surely as good. Yes,
the character sketching was keener,
though this fact can only be appreciated by those who have studied
(under) the professors for three or
four years.
One fact was evident all the time
the play was being given—that
kindly feeling lay beneath all the
humorous thrusts. At Princeton a
professor considers it a great honor
to have a song inserted in his honor
in the "fac" song, no matter how
hard the song hits him.
The Princeton professors realize
that boys are boys, and that they
may sometimes show their affection
for a "prof" by writing a song on
him, or by knocking him in a class
play. Boys respect and honor most
the professors they make most fun
of. THE NEWS-LETTER thinks that
the best way to establish that kindly,
personal relationship between professors and students, which should
certainly exist at Hopkins, is by the
production every year of such plays
as "Who's Who?

Sentiment a gai n s t freshmen
gambling at Virginia resulted in
the signing of the following resolution by 73.8 per cent. of the student body:
"We think that there should be
no gambling with first year men
by the old men, and that the student body should go on record as
opposed to all gambling by such
new men, because we feel that until
these men have been in college a
year they are not ordinarily capable
of deciding as to the wisdom of
gambling, nor of assuming the
responsibility for their decision.
* * * The morality of gambling
is not debated in taking up this
matter, but we think that as a problem of simple justice and expediency we do not believe that the
subject should remain in its present
unsatisfactory state."

To the Editor of THE

NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—Now that the college
year is drawing to a close, I take
great pleasure in writing to say how
much I have enjoyed THE NEwsLETTER this year. It has kept me
'informed of everything of general
interest that has happened at the
University during the past year, and
has kept me thoroughly in touch
with matters there. On the whole
I think that it is a very well run
paper. Its stories are very well
written up, generally, and are about
things of interest to most of us.
The one criticism which I have to
make is that the style of many of
the stories which aim to be entertaining, has come to be so regular
a performance that it is really
monotonous. A criticism of this
sort is really more a boost than a
knock, however, since it shows that
only minor points are below standard. In all the more important
respects I consider THE NEWSLETTER excellent.
In closing I wish to congratulate
the Board of Editors upon the excellence of the paper and the business management upon its success.
Yours very truly,
T. W. BRUNE, ex-I5.

The Senior Class Day.
Monday afternoon, June 9, at
three o'clock, the senior class day
exercises were held. There was
plenty of room for all, and all the
students were invited to attend.
Music was rendered by A. Roland Gminder. The salutatory address was given by the honorary
president of the class, Prof. Wilfred
P. Mustard. The class poem, written by J. S. Dickinson (published
in THE NEWS-LETTER, No. 27),
was read by J. Earle Uhler. The
valedictorial oration was made by
J. S. Dickinson. The chief feature of the exercises was the class
play, written specially for the occasion by Messrs. Rusk, Dickinson,
Wolman and Hildebrandt. The play
is entitled "Who's Who," and is in
two acts. We will let the play speak
for itself, and are printing it in full
in our columns, For those who

Following the baseball game the
Blacks again defeated the Reds,
this time in lacrosse. The game,
which resulted in a score of 3 to
o, was featured by the star playing of Captain Julian Marshall, of
the Blacks. Getz and Sattler were
the other stars of the contest.
The freak events afforded a
great deal of amusement. Uhler
was the winner of the meet, going
14 points. He won the hobbleskirt race in fine style, his long
legs enabling him to hop along
much faster than the shorter entrants. He also won the sack race,
and with Getz, shared the honors
of the three-legged contest. Pieper
won the potato race in great form.
"Freddie" Lee refereed the contests.
After the games, the seniors
went to Thompson's Sea Girt
House, where they enjoyed a fine
supper, followed by speech making
ancl singing.
A feature of the athletic contest
was the neat program gotten up
by the committee, consisting of
Meekins and Breuninger. These
men deserve credit for their success in arranging such a successful and amusing meet.

left the boat, wishing the Senior
Week Committee had not made us
come in so early.

LACROSSE GAME WITH TORONTO
Ad Club Arranges Big Contest—Hopkins
Rooters Must Be in Stands Before Half-past Three.

An All-Johns Hopkins lacrosse
team, having in its lineup some of
the best players turned out in
recent years, wit meet the Toronto
Athletics on Homewood field on
Thursday afternoon at 4.30 o'clock
as part of the schedule of the Associated Advertising Clubs' program of festivities during their
convention week in this city.
In selecting lacrosse as the particular sport that would be/interesting to the advertisers, a unique

compliment was paid Johns Hopkins. It was seen that a game between the 'Varsity and the Toronto
Athletics, considered by many the
best twelve on this continent, would
be close and interesting. The Canadians have been champions of the
Senior Interassociation Lacrosse
League of Canada for three years,
and their style of play is considered
standard by the Northern twelves.

Dr. J. Morris Slemons, associate
professor of obstetrics at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital, has accepted the
offer to become director of the new
Women's Clinic and professor of
obstetrics and gynecology at the
University of California. He will
leave Baltimore on July 15, and
will take up his new duties on
August 15. Dr. Slemons took his
A.B. degree here in 1897, and his
M.D. in 1901.
Dr. von Noorden,son of the prominent Vienna physician, will become
one of the assistant resident physicans at the hospital, and is expected
to assume his new duties in October.

The Faculty Reception.

After the conferring of degrees
Tuesday afternoon, the graduates
can look forward to the evening,
when the faculty of the University
will tender them a reception in McCoy Hall. This is always the .most
enjoyable social event of the whole
school year. It beats the best of
the cotillons. The event is always
a sort of cosmopolitan affair. Dress
suits and white flannels are both
seen; gay young A.B.'s with their
pretty partners are mixed among
the papas and admiring mammas.
° eems to be an abunThere always s
dance of all sorts of delicacies, and
when the floor has been newly
greased after the final "exams," the
fine dance music is enough to set
anyone's toes to tipping the floor.
The guests are invited to enter McCoy Hall by the south door, and
they will be received at 9 P. M.
Admission. will be by ticket only.

BALTIMORE, MD., JUNE 9, 1913.
Rooting Next Thursday.

The plan to have a rooting section for the game with the Toronto
Athletics deserves our most earnest
support. At Homewood, on Thursday, will be gathered a crowd of
big business men from every State
in the union. It is up to us, we
who are not lacrosse players, to
show that Hopkins has got as
much college spirit as any college
in the country. We must so thoroughly • impress the name "Hopkins" on those advertising men that
they shall never forget us.
Of course everybody is going to
the game—that goes without saying. There is to be a roped off
section under the old pine tree.
As the game is called at fourthirty, we should have the stand
filled with Hopkins rooters by four
o'clock, for fear the crowd will disregard our ropes, and fill the section.
"Freddie" Lee will be on hand, in
his usual form. But is is up to
you, you who know the cheers, to
come up in :that section and YELL.
We are champions of the Southern Division. Here's a long 'rah
with a daisy on the end for the
International Championship!
1913's Achievements.

This year's graduating class is
most to be commended for its
praiseworthy exertions in making
the second annual Senior Week a
success. Last year the novelty of
their doings made it easier for
1912 to get the necessary support
of the rest of the college. This
year the task was more severe.
That Chairman Richardson and his
sub-chairman have given us a most
pleasurable week can best be
brought out by a short summary
of the different festivities.
The most frequently used phrase
in connection with the senior prom

was "Best-ever." Everyone on
the "Annapolis" wished the machinery had broken before we got
to Fort Howard, that we might
have remained on the water hours
longer. The field day and dinner
of Saturday will long remain a
bright spot in 1913's memories of
Johns Hopkins. The play this
afternoon was a giggle and a gasp
from curtain to curtain. In brief,
the seniors so far surpassed the
Senior Week of last year that the
three other classes are wondering
how they are to maintain such a
record.
And the seniors have done more;
they have revived an old tradition. After a lapse of four years
another "Hullabaloo" has come before the public. The class of 1913,
and particularly the Board of Editors, deserves high commendation
for the quality of their book. From
cover to cover it is cleverly gotten
up; the binding is very attractive,
and the interior ably fulfills the
promise of the outside.
Manager Richardson wants everybody to buy their "Hullabaloos" before next Saturday. The increase
crom $2.00 to $2.50 in the cost of
the book has been made necessary
to clear expenses.

in being able to announce that it is
officially reported that a majority of
the undergraduates passed their examinations. We sympathize with

fOWNES

The Senior Play.

We hold it to be a self-evident
truth thdt comparisons are odious.
Therefore, we shall not compare
this year's senior play with the one
given last year, although it certainly
was more ambitious; it was built
around a real plot, which, though
simple, held the interest of every
hearer from beginning to end; and
the staging was far better. The
acting was surely as good. Yes,
the character sketching was keener,
though this fact can only be appreciated by those who have studied
(under) the professors for three or
four years.
One fact was evident all the time
the play was being given—that
kindly feeling lay beneath all the
humorous thrusts. At Princeton a
professor considers it a great honor
to have a song inserted in his honor
in the "fac" song, no matter how
hard the song hits him.
The Princeton professors realize
that boys are boys, and that they
may sometimes show their affection
for a "prof" by writing a song on
him, or by knocking him in a class
play. Boys respect and honor most
the professors they make most fun
of. THE NEWS-LETTER thinks that
the best way to establish that kindly,
personal relationship between professors and students, which should
certainly exist at Hopkins, is by the
production every year of such plays
as "Who's Who?

Sentiment a gai n s t freshmen
gambling at Virginia resulted in
the signing of the following resolution by 73.8 per cent. of the student body:
"We think that there should be
no gambling with first year men
by the old men, and that the student body should go on record as
opposed to all gambling by such
new men, because we feel that until
these men have been in college a
year they are not ordinarily capable
of deciding as to the wisdom of
gambling, nor of assuming the
responsibility for their decision.
* * * The morality of gambling
is not debated in taking up this
matter, but we think that as a problem of simple justice and expediency we do not believe that the
subject should remain in its present
unsatisfactory state."

To the Editor of THE

NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—Now that the college
year is drawing to a close, I take
great pleasure in writing to say how
much I have enjoyed THE NEwsLETTER this year. It has kept me
'informed of everything of general
interest that has happened at the
University during the past year, and
has kept me thoroughly in touch
with matters there. On the whole
I think that it is a very well run
paper. Its stories are very well
written up, generally, and are about
things of interest to most of us.
The one criticism which I have to
make is that the style of many of
the stories which aim to be entertaining, has come to be so regular
a performance that it is really
monotonous. A criticism of this
sort is really more a boost than a
knock, however, since it shows that
only minor points are below standard. In all the more important
respects I consider THE NEWSLETTER excellent.
In closing I wish to congratulate
the Board of Editors upon the excellence of the paper and the business management upon its success.
Yours very truly,
T. W. BRUNE, ex-I5.

The Senior Class Day.
Monday afternoon, June 9, at
three o'clock, the senior class day
exercises were held. There was
plenty of room for all, and all the
students were invited to attend.
Music was rendered by A. Roland Gminder. The salutatory address was given by the honorary
president of the class, Prof. Wilfred
P. Mustard. The class poem, written by J. S. Dickinson (published
in THE NEWS-LETTER, No. 27),
was read by J. Earle Uhler. The
valedictorial oration was made by
J. S. Dickinson. The chief feature of the exercises was the class
play, written specially for the occasion by Messrs. Rusk, Dickinson,
Wolman and Hildebrandt. The play
is entitled "Who's Who," and is in
two acts. We will let the play speak
for itself, and are printing it in full
in our columns, For those who
wish copies of the play and who are

Following the baseball game the
Blacks again defeated the Reds,
this time in lacrosse. The game,
which resulted in a score of 3 to
o, was featured by the star playing of Captain Julian Marshall, of
the Blacks. Getz and Sattler were
the other stars of the contest.
The freak events afforded a
great deal of amusement. Uhler
was the winner of the meet, going
14 points. He won the hobbleskirt race in fine style, his long
legs enabling him to hop along
much faster than the shorter entrants. He also won the sack race,
and with Getz, shared the honors
of the three-legged contest. Pieper
won the potato race in great form.
"Freddie" Lee refereed the contests.
After the games, the seniors
went to Thompson's Sea Girt
House, where they enjoyed a fine
supper, followed by speech making
ancl singing.
A feature of the athletic contest
was the neat program gotten up
by the committee, consisting of
Meekins and Breuninger. These
men deserve credit for their success in arranging such a successful and amusing meet.
Great was the disgust when Baltimore was reached and everyone
left the boat, wishing the Senior
Week Committee had not made us
come in so early.
